newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli shares shed early gains to close down.
newsitem.headline: Israeli shares shed early gains to close down.

text.p: Israeli shares closed lower in volatile trading on Monday as investors remained indifferent to a cabinet decision to postpone voting on a key part of a capital market reform package, traders said.
The benchmark Mishtanim index of the top 100 shares fell 0.27 percent, or 0.49 points, to 178.70 on low turnover of 60 million shekels against 52 million on Sunday.
The Maof 25 blue chip index lost 0.44 percent to 187.58.

"It is difficult to say why the market fell today. Trading opened with nice gains but later the trend changed. The reason might be that the market was affected by a similar change in trend in the options market," said Danniella Finn, head of sales at Batucha Securities and Investments.
"The decision on the Brodett report (the capital market reform) did not affect trading today and investors are waiting to see what the government decides in two weeks," Finn said.

The cabinet adopted on Monday morning only part of the Finance Ministry's reform package recommended by a panel, headed by the ministry's director general, David Brodett. Measures concerning savings, including a politically sensitive tax on savings of less than 10 years, will be voted on in two weeks.
"The market is really sick and nothing is happening in it. Without the tax on savings the (Brodett) report is meaningless," said Amir Eyal at Epsilon Securities.
"The government will never tax saving plans. I see no reason for a change in the market in the near future," he said.

The most active shares were Bank Leumi, which fell 2.0 percent to 346 on volume of 3.9 million shekels; Israel Corp, which lost 1.0 percent to 17,265 on turnover of 3.3 million shekels; and Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, which gained 0.25 percent to 135,734 on volume of 3.0 million shekels.
